title: 114_hr3989
content: The Act titled "Support Our Military Caregivers Act" allows for external clinical review of denied applications by caregivers of veterans. The "Support Our Military Caregivers Act" amends Section 1720G of title 38, United States Code to allow for external clinical review of denied caregiver applications by veterans. The Secretary can determine the level of personal care services a veteran needs, and caregivers can request a reconsideration based on changes in the veteran's health. The Secretary can also revoke assistance provided under this section. Independent contractors awarded contracts through competitive processes can carry out these services. The external clinical review process for caregivers and family caregivers under this title requires reviewers to have specific qualifications and not be financially tied to non-Department providers. The reviews must be conducted by a panel of healthcare professionals who do not treat the individual seeking the review. The external clinical review process for caregivers and family caregivers under this title requires reviewers to have specific qualifications and not be financially tied to non-Department providers. The reviews must be conducted by a panel of healthcare professionals who do not treat the individual seeking the review. The external clinical reviews shall be based on information from the application, include input from the individual and veteran, review initial clinical assessments, collect and share necessary information with the Secretary. The Secretary may consider but is not obligated to follow the determination made by an independent contractor in deciding on assistance applications. The final decision can differ from the contractor's determination if clinically supported documentation is provided. External clinical reviews must be completed within 120 days, with results shared within 30 days of the contractor's recommendation. The Secretary may consider an independent contractor's determination but is not obligated to follow it when deciding on assistance applications. The final decision, supported by clinical documentation, must be communicated to the veteran and the individual making the election. Notification includes an explanation of the recommended decision, facts, regulations, and clinical rationale. Veterans applying for caregiver assistance are informed of their ability to make an election. These provisions do not affect veterans' claims for disability compensation. The amendments made by subsection (a) apply to elections under section 1720G of title 38, United States Code, for caregiver assistance and family caregivers. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs must not have made a final decision on these applications as of the enactment of this Act. The amendments apply to elections for caregiver assistance and family caregivers under section 1720G of title 38, United States Code. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs must not have made a final decision on these applications at the enactment of this Act. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will issue directives for the Family Caregiver Program, including eligibility criteria. The Comptroller General will report on the eligibility determination process, appeals adjudication, and periodic reevaluation for program participants. The Family Caregiver Program includes comprehensive assistance for family caregivers and general caregiver support services established by section 1720G of title 38, United States Code. SEC. 4. MODIFICATION TO LIMITATION ON AWARDS AND BONUSES. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs shall ensure that the aggregate amount of awards and bonuses paid in a fiscal year does not exceed specified amounts for fiscal years 2017 through 2024. The House of Representatives passed the bill on May 23, 2016. Karen L. Haas is the Clerk.
